questions.question: Match the following: 1) Perkins Tonometer a) 2) Tonopen b) 3) Pulsair tonometer

A 62-year-old man with a history of Glaucoma undergoes visual field testing to assess his peripheral vision. The test involves moving a stimulus of constant size and intensity from a non-seeing area into a seeing area to determine the boundaries of his visual field. Which type of perimetry is being described?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Goldmann perimetry Explanation: Goldmann perimetry is a type of manual kinetic perimetry. In this technique, a stimulus of constant size and intensity is moved from a non-seeing area (usually the far periphery) towards the center of vision until the patient detects it. This method allows for a detailed mapping of the visual field boundary. In kinetic perimetry, the stimulus of known luminance is moved from a peripheral non seeing point towards the center till it is perceived to establish the isopters. Various methods of kinetic perimetry: Confrontation method Confrontation visual field testing involves having the patient look directly at the examiner's eye or nose. It compares the visual field of the patient and the physician. Lister's perimetry It has a metallic semicircular arc, graded in degrees, with a white dot for fixation in the center. The arc can be rotated in different meridians. It is useful for peripheral field charting. Not used nowadays Tangent screen scotometry (Bjerrum Screen) It is useful to evaluate the central and paracentral area (30°) of the visual field Goldmann's perimetry lt consists of a hemispherical dome. Its main advantage over the tangent screen is that the test conditions and the intensity of the target are always the same. It permits greater reproducibility. Automated perimetry ( Option B): Static perimetry where stationary stimuli of varying intensities are presented at fixed locations in the visual field. It doesn't involve moving stimuli. Frequency doubling perimetry ( Option C): Static perimetry that uses a specific stimulus (a sinusoidal grating) to test contrast sensitivity and is particularly useful for detecting early glaucomatous damage. SWAP (Option D): Static perimetry technique that uses a blue light stimulus on a yellow background to selectively test the function of blue-yellow ganglion cells, which may be affected early in glaucoma.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient with primary open-angle glaucoma undergoes visual field testing. Which of the following visual field defects is considered the earliest clinically significant field defect occurring in glaucoma? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Small ring-shaped paracentral scotoma- Explanation: The earliest clinically significant field defect to appear in patients of glaucoma is small of fixation point ring-shaped paracentral scotoma . It may appear either below or above the blind spot in Bjerrum's area (an arcuate area extending above and below the blind spot between 10° and 20° Visual Field Defects in Primary Open Angle Glaucoma 1. Isopter contraction Mild generalized constriction of central as well as peripheral field 2. Baring of blind spot Early glaucomatous change, but nonspecific and of limited diagnostic value 3. Small ring-shaped paracentral scotoma Earliest clinically significant field defect; appears in Bjerrum's area 4. Seidel's scotoma Paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot to form a sickle-shaped defect 5. Arcuate or Bjerrum's scotoma Formed at a later stage by extension of Seidel's scotoma in an area above or below the fixation point 6. Ring or double arcuate scotoma Develops when the two arcuate scotomas join together 7. Roenne's central nasal step An area of depression above or below the horizontal meridian on the nasal side. This is due to the two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meet to form a sharp right-angled gap. 8. Peripheral nasal step Appear sometimes at an early stage; peripheral nasal step results from unequal contraction of the peripheral isopter 9. Advanced glaucomatous field defects Visual field loss gradually spreads peripherally, eventually only the central and temporal island of vision is left behind.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient undergoes a comprehensive eye examination including visual field testing. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: A scotoma is an area of decreased vision surrounded by normal vision
options.B: An isopter is a line connecting points of equal light sensitivity and size detection in the visual field
options.C: The blind spot is a type of absolute scotoma
options.D: The visual field extends maximally in the superior direction

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The visual field extends maximally in the superior direction Explanation: Visual field is the peripheral vision. It extends maximally in the temporal direction and minimally in the superior direction . The extent of the visual field: (mnemonic: TINS) Temporally: 90° to 100° Inferiorly: 70° Nasally: 60° Superiorly: 50° Scotoma ( Option A ) is an area of decreased vision surrounded by normal vision. Relative scotoma is related to a decrease in sensitivity of the retina (one is no longer able to perceive some or all colors except for white). Absolute scotoma is the total absence of visual perception, e.g., physiological blind spot. Isopter ( Option B): Line connecting points of equal light sensitivity and size detection in the visual field. Physiological blind spot (Option C): Corresponds to the area where the optic nerve exits the eye, which lacks photoreceptors. It is a type of absolute scotoma. It is located approximately 10 to 20 degrees from fixation and 1.5 degrees below the horizontal meridian . Reference: Visual Field Defects- Pubmed Neuroanatomy- Visual pathway Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Page 362-364

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient is being evaluated for suspected primary open-angle glaucoma. The ophthalmologist wants to perform a thorough examination of the optic nerve head to detect glaucomatous changes. Which of the following techniques is considered the examination of choice for evaluating fundus changes in this patient?

options.B: Slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination with non-contact lens

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination with non-contact lens Explanation: The examination of choice for detecting fundal changes in a glaucoma suspect is Slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination with non-contact lens . The non-contact lenses of +78 or +90 dioptres are commonly used. Investigations to examine fundus changes in Glaucoma Slit Lamp Biomicroscopy Investigation of choice Lenses used: Contact Lens: Goldman three mirror Non Contact Lens: Convex ( +78D, +90D) or Concave (Hruby Lens) Direct Ophthalmoscopy (Option A) No depth perception as the examiner uses only one eye. Indirect Ophthalmoscopy (Option D) Magnification is less, hence it is not used to examine the disc and macula. OCT (Optical coherence tomography) (Option C) Useful method to measure optic disc diameter, CDR, NRR thickness and optic disc area Scanning Laser Polarimetry Nerve fiber analyzer - To measure thickness of nerve fiber layer Reference: US Ophthalmic Review Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Pages 21-27

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman with a family history of glaucoma presents with mild visual disturbances. Her intraocular pressure is measured to be 24 mmHg in both eyes. On dilated fundus examination, the following findings are noted: The cup-to-disc ratio of 0.5 Splinter hemorrhages at the optic disc margin Wedge-shaped retinal nerve fiber layer defects on red-free light examination What stage of glaucomatous optic disc changes is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Early glaucomatous changes Explanation: Early glaucomatous changes are indicated by signs such as: Cup-to-disc ratio of >0.3. Asymmetry of the cups : A cup-to-disc ratio difference greater than 0.2 between two eyes. Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin. Retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) defects - wedge-shaped dark areas seen on the red-free light examination - an early indicator of glaucomatous damage. Advanced glaucomatous changes Cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7–0.9 Significant neuroretinal rim thinning Vessel bayonetting Glaucomatous optic atrophy Complete destruction of the neural tissue Deeply excavated and white optic disc. Cavernous optic atrophy - large caverns or lacunae are formed due to: Raised IOP leading to modulation of lamina cribrosa. Ischaemic atrophy of the nerve fibers without a corresponding increase of supporting glial tissue. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Pages 353, 354, 355, 369 Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Pages 695, 696

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman with a long history of untreated open-angle glaucoma presents with gradual peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination reveals advanced optic disc cupping. Which of the following vascular changes is most characteristic of progressive glaucomatous optic neuropathy?

options.C: Arterial attenuation with increased vein diameter

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nasal displacement of retinal vessels Explanation: In advanced glaucoma, there is progressive optic disc cupping. A characteristic feature of this process is the nasal displacement of retinal vessels, as the optic nerve head undergoes excavation. This displacement is caused by the pulling of the retinal vessels toward the nasal side as the cupping advances, changing the shape of lamina cribrosa. Vascular Blood Vessel Alignment Changes in Glaucoma: Early glaucomatous changes: Splinter hemorrhages on or near the optic disc margin with pallor areas on the disc. Advanced glaucomatous changes: Bayonetting sign - Double angulation of a blood vessel. Nasal shifting of retinal vessels. Pulsations of the retinal arterioles are seen at the disc margin - a pathognomonic sign. Glaucomatous optic atrophy: the nerve fibers undergo ischemic atrophy , but there is no proportional increase in the supporting glial tissue. Inferior displacement of retinal vessels (Option A) : This is not characteristic of glaucomatous optic neuropathy; vessels typically shift nasally. Arterial attenuation with increased vein diameter (Option C) : While arterial narrowing can be seen in certain conditions, this pattern is more typical of hypertensive retinopathy. Radial peripapillary capillary obliteration (Option D) : This finding is more associated with ischemic optic neuropathy, not typical in glaucoma. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Page 352, 353

questions.question: A 58-year-old male with a family history of glaucoma presents for a comprehensive eye exam. His visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes, and his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 23 mmHg in the right eye and 21 mmHg in the left eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals the following optic disc findings in the right eye: Cup-to-disc ratio: 0.7 vertically Neuroretinal rim thinning: More pronounced in the superior and inferior quadrants Peripapillary atrophy present No optic disc hemorrhages noted All of the following statements are correct regarding the optic disc assessment in this patient except?

options.A: The optic disc appearance follows the ISNT rule, indicating a healthy optic nerve.
options.B: The cup-to-disc ratio indicates early glaucomatous damage.
options.C: The absence of optic disc hemorrhages does not rule out glaucoma.
options.D: Peripapillary atrophy is commonly associated with glaucoma and warrants further monitoring.

questions.explanation: nerve. Correct Answer: A) The optic disc appearance follows the ISNT rule, indicating a healthy optic nerve. Explanation: All of the findings are consistent with early glaucomatous changes except that the disc shows superior and inferior neuroretinal rim thinning violating the ISNT rule. The patient's optic disc shows several characteristic features of glaucomatous optic neuropathy : 1. Increased cup-to-disc ratio (0.7): A ratio greater than 0.6 is suspicious for glaucoma. 2. Superior and inferior neuroretinal rim thinning: This violates the ISNT rule. 3. Peripapillary atrophy present In glaucoma, there is a progressive loss of retinal nerve fibers, leading to enlargement of the cup and thinning of the neuroretinal rim. The ISNT rule (Option A) states that, in a healthy optic nerve, the neuroretinal rim thickness typically follows a pattern, being the broadest in: Inferior > Superior > Nasal > Temporal . Changes in this rule, particularly inferior or superior rim thinning, is often an early sign of glaucomatous damage, and does not indicate a healthy optic nerve, making this an incorrect statement. The cup-to-disc ratio indicates early glaucomatous damage (Option B) is correct. A cup-to-disc ratio of 0.7 is considered enlarged and suspicious for glaucoma. Normal cup-to-disc ratio is ≤ 0.3. The absence of optic disc hemorrhages does not rule out glaucoma (Option C) is correct. Their presence is a risk factor for the development and progression of glaucoma. They are more common in NTG, but can also occur in healthy individuals as well as patients with systemic vascular disease. Peripapillary atrophy is commonly associated with glaucoma and warrants further monitoring (Option D) is correct. Peripapillary atrophy surrounding the optic nerve head may be of significance in glaucoma and may be a sign of early damage in patients with ocular hypertension.

questions.question: Which device is a non contact tonometer that is based on the principle of corneal hysteresis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ocular Response Analyzer Explanation: The Ocular Response Analyzer (ORA) : The Ocular Response Analyzer (ORA) is a non-contact tonometer designed to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) and corneal biomechanics. It uses air impulses to deform the cornea, recording the inward and outward movement to assess corneal elasticity or hysteresis. The device calculates two corneal parameters: corneal hysteresis and corneal resistance factor, providing insights into the cornea's viscoelastic properties. ORA's corneal-compensated IOP measurements are less influenced by corneal properties compared to traditional methods like Goldmann applanation tonometry (GAT), but it may overestimate IOP, especially at elevated levels. Other Latest Tonometer: Pascal Dynamic Contour Tonometry (DCT) is a contact tonometer designed to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) by directly conforming to the corneal surface. It uses a contoured, pressure-sensitive tip that matches the shape of the cornea, allowing continuous and dynamic monitoring of IOP. It additionally measures a parameter called ocular pulse amplitude (OPA), which reflects the difference between systolic and diastolic IOP during the cardiac cycle DCT readings are generally considered more independent of corneal properties compared to Goldmann applanation tonometry (GAT). The reading does not depend on CCT (central corneal thickness). Fixed force tonometers: Fixed force tonometers use a constant force applied to the cornea and measure the area of applanation. Two notable examples of fixed-force tonometers are: 1. MaklaKov tonometer: 2. Barraquer tonometer: Schiotz tonometer (Option A) is an indentation tonometer. It doesn't measure corneal hysteresis. Goldmann applanation tonometer (Option B) is the gold standard for IOP measurement and is based on Imbert-Fick law. Pneumatonometer (Option D) is a non-contact applanation tonometer, not based on corneal hysteresis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about aqueous humor are incorrect? Aqueous humor is formed from the non-pigmented epithelium of ciliary processes Aqueous constitutes 99% water The non-pigmented epithelium has a Na/Cl symporter responsible for aqueous humor secretion. The rate of formation of Aqueous humor is 2.3 microlitres/min
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Only 3 is incorrect Explanation: The non-pigmented epithelium has a Na/K/ATPase pump responsible for aqueous humor secretion. Aqueous humor : Aqueous humor is formed from the non-pigmented epithelium of ciliary processes Ciliary processes have blood vessels, stroma, and two layers of epithelium. The inner epithelium is pigmented and the outer epithelium is the non-pigmented epithelium The non-pigmented epithelium has a Na/K/ATPase pump and is responsible for aqueous humor secretion. Aqueous constitutes 99.9% water and 0.1% solutes. The diagram above shows the outflow. The aqueous that is formed in the posterior chamber goes through the pupil into the anterior chamber, and through the trabecular pathway. When it passes through the uveo-sclera, it is called the uveoscleral pathway. Process of aqueous humor production: Diffusion Ultrafiltration Secretion (maximum formation) The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2.3 microlitres/min The total volume of aqueous humor is 0.31mL

questions.question: Which type of tonometer measures intraocular pressure (IOP) by assessing how much a plunger indents the eye?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Schiotz Tonometer Explanation: A tonometer is an instrument used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) within the eye. This measurement is crucial in diagnosing and managing glaucoma and other eye conditions. Schiotz Tonometer measures IOP by the amount of corneal indentation caused by a plunger. It is a type of indentation tonometer. Types of Tonometry: 1. Indentation Tonometry: Concept: Measures IOP by how much a plunger indents the eye; softer eyes indent more than harder eyes. Schiotz Tonometer (Option A): Most widely used tonometer in the world. Advantages: Inexpensive, simple, and reliable. Disadvantages: Gives false readings in eyes with abnormal scleral rigidity (e.g., high myopes, post-surgery). 2. Applanation Tonometry: Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A). Goldmann Tonometer (Option B): Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp. Technique: Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein. Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light. Prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch. IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten. Variable force tonometers: Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann) (Option C) Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP) (Option D) Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins It has a different set of prisms It operates with a motor Pulsair (non-contact tonometer) Airpuff (non-contact tonometer) Grolman (non-contact tonometer) Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation) MacKay Marg (based on both indentation and applanation) Rebound tonometer Transpalpebral Tonometer Fixed force tonometer: Maklakov tonometer Barraquer tonometer

questions.question: A 58-year-old man presents for a routine eye examination. His intraocular pressure (IOP) is consistently measured at 23 mm Hg on multiple occasions. He reports no visual symptoms, and his fundus examination shows no abnormalities. Visual field testing reveals no defects. Based on these findings, which of the following diagnoses is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ocular Hypertension Explanation: The patient has elevated IOP consistently above 21 mm Hg without any visual field defects or fundus changes. These characteristics are consistent with ocular hypertension . ASPECT OCULAR HYPERTENSION (Option B) NORMAL TENSION GLAUCOMA (Option A) Characteristic Features IOP consistently above 21 mm Hg (No Damage) No Fundus findings No visual field defects IOP is normal. Fundus changes Present Visual field defect present The anterior chamber angle is open on gonioscopy, and there is no secondary cause for the changes. Risk Factors Consistent IOP >30 mm Hg. Central corneal thickness <550 µm. Vertical cup-to-disc ratio >0.7. Increased age. Increased pattern standard deviation (PSD) on Humphrey visual field test. Disc hemorrhages (splinter hemorrhages near or over the disc). Raynaud phenomenon Migraine: Increased risk. Nocturnal systemic hypotension: Low blood pressure during the night, or overtreated systemic hypertension. Reduced blood flow velocity in the ophthalmic artery Management When these risk factors are present, treatment may be initiated similarly to open-angle glaucoma, but with a less aggressive approach. Medical Treatment: Target the IOP levels to be around 12-14 mm Hg. Prostaglandin analogues (e.g., latanoprost) are preferred for their effective ocular hypotensive effect. Beta blockers and adrenergic drugs should be avoided due to potential adverse effects on optic nerve perfusion. Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma (Option C): This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sudden eye pain, blurred vision, and possibly nausea, and usually shows a significant increase in IOP along with a closed anterior chamber angle. The patient’s IOP is elevated but there are no acute symptoms or angle closure present. Secondary Glaucoma (Option D): This type of glaucoma results from an underlying condition that causes increased IOP. There is no indication in this case of a secondary cause for the elevated IOP, such as trauma, inflammation, or a systemic condition, so secondary glaucoma is not the most appropriate diagnosis. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Pages 347, 367, 370, 378 Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Pages 1392, 1393

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with a history of glaucoma reports worsening vision, headaches, and difficulty with reading. Her IOP shows significant fluctuations throughout the day, and fundus examination reveals optic disc cupping with visual field defects. Which of the following about IOP changes in POAG is false?

options.A: Diurnal variation includes a morning rise in IOP in 20% of cases and a biphasic rise in 55% of cases.
options.B: In early POAG, IOP is consistently above 21 mm Hg.
options.C: IOP is higher in winter due to seasonal variations.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) In early POAG, IOP is consistently above 21 mm Hg. Explanation: The diagnosis of Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG) in this case is supported by significant diurnal fluctuations in intraocular pressure (IOP), characteristic optic disc cupping, and specific visual field defects. In the initial stages of POAG, IOP may not be consistently elevated and often shows exaggerated diurnal variation. Non-Specific Symptoms of POAG Mild headache and eye ache. Difficulty with reading and close work due to accommodative failure and frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. Delayed dark adaptation, becoming problematic in later stages. Significant vision loss and potential blindness in untreated cases. On Examination- 3 Salient features: IOP Changes Fundus Changes Visual field defect Intraocular Pressure (IOP) Changes in POAG Initial Stage: IOP may not be consistently high; diurnal variation (fluctuation throughout the day) is exaggerated. Repeated measurements (every 3-4 hours) are needed to detect this. (Option B) Diurnal Variation Patterns: Morning rise in IOP: 20% of cases Afternoon rise in IOP: 25% of cases Biphasic rise in IOP (morning and afternoon): 55% of cases (Option A) Suspicious Variation: A variation in IOP of over 5 mm Hg is suspicious, and over 8 mm Hg is diagnostic of glaucoma. Later Stages: IOP becomes consistently elevated above 21 mm Hg, typically ranging from 30 to 45 mm Hg. General Factors Affecting Intraocular Pressure (IOP) Heredity: Influences IOP through multifactorial mechanisms. Age: IOP increases after age 40 due to reduced aqueous outflow. Sex: IOP is equal between sexes from ages 20-40; however, older females tend to have a higher increase in IOP compared to males. Diurnal Variation: Higher IOP in the morning and lower in the evening; glaucomatous eyes show greater fluctuation than normal eyes. Postural Variations: IOP increases when moving from a sitting to a supine position. Seasonal Variations: Higher IOP is observed in winter months. (Option C) Blood Pressure: No long-term effect on IOP, but glaucoma prevalence is slightly higher in hypertensives. Osmotic Pressure: Increased plasma osmolarity lowers IOP and vice versa. Drugs: General anesthetics, alcohol, tobacco, caffeine, and steroids increase IOP; some antiglaucoma drugs lower IOP. Exercise: Strenuous exercise lowers IOP temporarily. (Option D) Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Pages 349, 350, 351 Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page 693

questions.question: Which gene mutation is linked to the development of primary open angle glaucoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) MYOC gene Explanation: The MYOC gene (myocilin) is most commonly associated with primary open angle glaucoma (POAG). POAG has been associated with at least 20 loci in the human genome, the most important ones being: Myocillin - MYOC gene Optineurin gene - OPTN gene WTR - 36 LOXL1 gene (Option B): LOXL1 mutations are associated with pseudoexfoliation syndrome, which is the commonest cause of secondary open angle glaucoma. PAX6 gene (Option C): PAX6 gene is crucial for eye development and is associated with congenital eye disorders, including aniridia. RB1 gene (Option D): RB1 gene is primarily associated with retinoblastoma. While it plays a role in tumor suppression, it is not related to the pathogenesis of primary open-angle glaucoma. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Page 350, 379, 402, 860

questions.question: Which of the following is not a recognized risk factor for Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma?

options.B: Diastolic perfusion pressure of more than 55 mm Hg

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Diastolic perfusion pressure of more than 55 mm Hg Explanation: A diastolic perfusion pressure of more than 55 mm Hg is generally not considered to be a risk factor for POAG. Lower diastolic perfusion pressure (<55 mm Hg) is a significant risk factor for glaucoma. Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG) Characteristics: Intraocular Pressure: Elevated (>21 mm Hg) on multiple occasions. Anterior Chamber Angle: Open and normal in appearance. Optic Disc: Characteristic cupping. Visual Field: Specific defects present. Risk Factors: Elevated IOP: Asymmetry of IOP of ≥ 4 mmHg is considered significant. (Option A) Family History: Higher risk in siblings (10%) and offspring (4%). Involves polygenic inheritance with genes like MYOC, OPTN, and WDR36 . (Option C) Age: Increased risk with age, especially between the 5th and 7th decades of life. Race: Higher prevalence and severity in Black individuals compared to Whites. Myopia: Increased risk in myopic individuals. (Option D) Thinner Central Corneal Thickness (CCT) (<555 µm) is an independent risk factor. Cigarette Smoking: Increased risk Blood Pressure: Higher prevalence in hypertensives; diastolic perfusion pressure <55 mm Hg is a significant risk factor. (Option B) Thyrotoxicosis: Increased in Graves' ophthalmic disease. Corticosteroid Responsiveness: Greater risk of IOP rise with topical steroid therapy. Pathogenesis: The rise in IOP in POAG occurs due to decreased aqueous outflow facility. This is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening and apposition of Schlemm's canal wall. Contributing factors include thickening and sclerosis of the trabecular meshwork, narrowing of intertrabecular spaces, deposition of amorphous material in the juxtacanalicular space, and collapse of Schlemm's canal. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Page 350

questions.question: All the following statements about trabecular meshwork are true except;

options.A: It regulates the production of aqueous humor
options.C: It facilitates the drainage of aqueous humor from the anterior chamber of the eye
options.D: Trabecular meshwork has 3 parts and among the three, juxtacanalicular has the maximum resistance

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It regulates the production of aqueous humor Explanation: Trabecular meshwork has no role in the production of aqueous humor. Aqueous humor is produced from the non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process. Trabecular meshwork facilitates the drainage of aqueous humor from the anterior chamber of eye. (Option C) It has 3 parts: (Option D) Uveal trabecular meshwork Corneoscleral trabecular meshwork Juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork Trabecular meshwork secrete Glycosaminoglycans (Option B) Maximum resistance in trabecular meshwork is seen in Juxtacanalicular trabecular meshwork (Option D) Contractile properties are present due to the presence of actin and myosin Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Page 346 Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Pages 57, 680, 681

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the role of uveoscleral outflow in intraocular pressure regulation? alternative pathway to the conventional outflow route.

options.A: It involves the drainage of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal.
options.B: It accounts for the drainage of aqueous humor through the ciliary body and sclera, providing an
options.C: It is the process by which aqueous humor exits the eye through the vitreous body.
options.D: It describes the absorption of aqueous humor by the corneal endothelium.

questions.explanation: sclera, providing an alternative pathway to the conventional outflow route. Correct Answer: B) It accounts for the drainage of aqueous humor through the ciliary body and sclera, providing an alternative pathway to the conventional outflow route. Explanation: Uveoscleral outflow is an alternative route for aqueous humor drainage, distinct from the conventional trabecular meshwork and Schlemm's canal system. In this process, aqueous humor drains through the ciliary body and into the sclera. This route helps regulate intraocular pressure by providing an additional means for aqueous humor to exit the eye. (Options A, C, and D) describe different aspects of ocular physiology but do not accurately reflect the uveoscleral outflow pathway. The flow of aqueous humor: Non-pigmented epithelium of ciliary processes secreted in the posterior chamber via the pupil enters the anterior chamber. Through the angle of the anterior chamber, 90% (IOP dependent) Trabecular outflow: starts from trabecular meshwork via Schlemm's canal reaches the aqueous vein, and finally to the episcleral vein. 10% (IOP independent) Uveo-scleral outflow drains into supraciliary space. The aqueous enters the ciliary body through the iris root, ciliary body face, and uveal trabecular meshwork. Aqueous passes across the ciliary body between the bundles of ciliary muscles into the suprachoroidal space and is drained by the venous circulation of the ciliary body, choroid, and sclera.

questions.question: All the following constituents are more in aqueous humor compared to that of plasma except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Glucose Explanation: Due to the difficulty of substances entering the eye through the blood-aqueous barrier and the ease of their exit via drainage channels, many constituents of the aqueous humor are found in lower concentrations compared to blood, except for those that are actively secreted. Glucose levels in the aqueous humor are lower than those in plasma. Constituents that are more in aqueous than in plasma are: Lactate (due to anaerobic glycolysis) (Option A) Ascorbate (antioxidant) (Option B) Chloride Pyruvate (Option C) Blood Aqueous Barrier is formed by: Non-pigmented epithelium (Tight junction) Vascular endothelium of the iris Reference: Parsons Disease of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page 16f Myron Yanoff and Jay S. Duker, Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, Page 359
